dataIdInfo.idAbs: Calculates statistics on values of the land suitability raster within the zones of other dataset and reports the results in a number of tables.
dataIdInfo.idCredit: International Center for Tropical Agriculture - CIAT | Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation - CSIRO

tool.name: LandStatistics

param.name: in_raszone
param.dialogReference: An input raster that defines a zone. Float or double precision raster will be converted internally into 32-bit signed integer.
param.pythonReference: An input raster that defines a zone. Float or double precision raster will be converted internally into 32-bit signed integer.

param.name: rec_option
param.dialogReference:
Input raster zone data reclassification option:

  • NONE — This is the default option. If used on a float or double precision input raster zone data, the data will first be converted into a 32-bit integer and attribute table generated.

  • EQUAL INTERVAL— Reclassification option that will remap input raster zone data into equal range of values as per the number of classes stated.

  • RECLASS BY TABLE — Input raster zone data will be remaped based on value ranges declared in an INFO table, a CSV, a .dbf file, an Access table, or a text file. .xls remap table fields will not be loaded. To fully take advantage of this option, make sure you have three fields in your table – ‘from value’, ‘to value’ and ‘new value’. When defining values in the table, ensure field values are of the same numerical type. Click onthe Tool Help button for more instructions.
param.pythonReference:
Input raster zone data reclassification option:

  • NONE — This is the default option. If used on a float or double precision input raster zone data, the data will first be converted into a 32-bit integer and attribute table generated.

  • EQUAL INTERVAL— Reclassification option that will remap input raster zone data into equal range of values as per the number of classes stated.

  • RECLASS BY TABLE — Input raster zone data will be remaped based on value ranges declared in an INFO table, a CSV, a .dbf file, an Access table, or a text file. .xls remap table fields will not be loaded. To fully take advantage of this option, make sure you have three fields in your table – ‘from value’, ‘to value’ and ‘new value’. When defining values in the table, ensure field values are of the same numerical type. Click onthe Tool Help button for more instructions.

param.name: num_classes
param.dialogReference: An integer value that will determine the number of classes if EQUAL INTERVAL is used. The default is five.
param.pythonReference: An integer value that will determine the number of classes if EQUAL INTERVAL is used. The default is five.

param.name: in_remap_table_view
param.dialogReference: Input table with ranges to be used in reclassifying input raster zone data. Allowed table types include; INFO tables, CSV, .dbf files, Access tables, or a text file. .xls remap table fields will not be loaded. To fully take advantage of this option, make sure you have three fields in your table – ‘from value’, ‘to value’ and ‘new value’. When defining values in the table, ensure field values are of the same numerical type. Click onthe Tool Help button for more instructions.
param.pythonReference: Input table with ranges to be used in reclassifying input raster zone data. Allowed table types include; INFO tables, CSV, .dbf files, Access tables, or a text file. .xls remap table fields will not be loaded. To fully take advantage of this option, make sure you have three fields in your table – ‘from value’, ‘to value’ and ‘new value’. When defining values in the table, ensure field values are of the same numerical type. Click onthe Tool Help button for more instructions.

param.name: from_val_field
param.dialogReference:
Field holding the beginning value for each value range to be reclassified.

This is a numeric field of the input remap table.
param.pythonReference:
Field holding the beginning value for each value range to be reclassified.

This is a numeric field of the input remap table.

param.name: to_val_field
param.dialogReference:
Field holding the ending value for each value range to be reclassified.

This is a numeric field of the input remap table.
param.pythonReference:
Field holding the ending value for each value range to be reclassified.

This is a numeric field of the input remap table.

param.name: new_val_field
param.dialogReference:
Field holding the integer values to which each range should be changed.

This is an integer field of the input remap table.
param.pythonReference:
Field holding the integer values to which each range should be changed.

This is an integer field of the input remap table.

parameters.param:
Input value feature class is a polygon layer that contains field name.

Input value feature class is a polygon layer that contains field name.

param.name: fval_field
param.dialogReference: Input value feature class field name. Only strings are allowed any other data type will be filtered out.
param.pythonReference: Input value feature class field name. Only strings are allowed any other data type will be filtered out.

param.name: in_raster1
param.dialogReference: Raster Layer — Raster dataset on which to calculate statistics from.
param.pythonReference: Raster Layer — Raster dataset on which to calculate statistics from.

param.name: stat_type1
param.expression: ALL | MEAN | MAJORITY | MAXIMUM | MEDIAN | MINIMUM | MINORITY | RANGE | STANDARD DEVIATION | SUM | VARIETY
param.dialogReference:
Statistics Type — Statistics type to be calculated. The default value is ALL.

  • ALL — All of the statistics will be calculated. This is the default.

  • MEAN — Calculates the average of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MAJORITY — Determines the value that occurs most often of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MAXIMUM — Determines the largest value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MEDIAN — Determines the median value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MINIMUM — Determines the smallest value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MINORITY — Determines the value that occurs least often of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • RANGE — Calculates the difference between the largest and smallest value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • STD — Calculates the standard deviation of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • SUM — Calculates the total value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • VARIETY — Calculates the number of unique values for all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • Ignore NoData — Denotes whether NoData values in the Value input will influence the results of the zone that they fall within. The default value is ‘Yes’.

    • DATA — Within any particular zone, only cells that have a value in the input Value raster will be used in determining the output value for that zone. NoData cells in the Value raster will be ignored in the statistic calculation.
param.pythonReference:
Statistics Type — Statistics type to be calculated. The default value is ALL.

  • ALL — All of the statistics will be calculated. This is the default.

  • MEAN — Calculates the average of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MAJORITY — Determines the value that occurs most often of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MAXIMUM — Determines the largest value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MEDIAN — Determines the median value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MINIMUM — Determines the smallest value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MINORITY — Determines the value that occurs least often of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • RANGE — Calculates the difference between the largest and smallest value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • STD — Calculates the standard deviation of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • SUM — Calculates the total value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • VARIETY — Calculates the number of unique values for all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • Ignore NoData — Denotes whether NoData values in the Value input will influence the results of the zone that they fall within. The default value is ‘Yes’.

    • DATA — Within any particular zone, only cells that have a value in the input Value raster will be used in determining the output value for that zone. NoData cells in the Value raster will be ignored in the statistic calculation.

param.name: field_id1
param.dialogReference:
Field Identifier — String or alphanumeric values that will be concatenated with output table field headers. When choosing a Field Identifier value, please consider the following:

  • It should be unique.

  • It should NOT have more than two characters

  • Eliminate any character that is NOT alphanumeric or an underscore.

  • It should NOT start with underscore or a number.
param.pythonReference:
Field Identifier — String or alphanumeric values that will be concatenated with output table field headers. When choosing a Field Identifier value, please consider the following:

  • It should be unique.

  • It should NOT have more than two characters

  • Eliminate any character that is NOT alphanumeric or an underscore.

  • It should NOT start with underscore or a number.

Statistics Type — Statistics type to be calculated. The default value is ALL.

  • ALL — All of the statistics will be calculated. This is the default.

  • MEAN — Calculates the average of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MAJORITY — Determines the value that occurs most often of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MAXIMUM — Determines the largest value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MEDIAN — Determines the median value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MINIMUM — Determines the smallest value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • MINORITY — Determines the value that occurs least often of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • RANGE — Calculates the difference between the largest and smallest value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • STD — Calculates the standard deviation of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • SUM — Calculates the total value of all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • VARIETY — Calculates the number of unique values for all cells in the value raster that belong to the same zone as the output cell.

  • Ignore NoData — Denotes whether NoData values in the Value input will influence the results of the zone that they fall within. The default value is ‘Yes’.

    • DATA — Within any particular zone, only cells that have a value in the input Value raster will be used in determining the output value for that zone. NoData cells in the Value raster will be ignored in the statistic calculation.

param.name: field_id6
param.dialogReference:
Field Identifier — String or alphanumeric values that will be concatenated with output table field headers. When choosing a Field Identifier value, please consider the following:

  • It should be unique.

  • It should NOT have more than two characters

  • Eliminate any character that is NOT alphanumeric or an underscore.

  • It should NOT start with underscore or a number.
param.pythonReference:
Field Identifier — String or alphanumeric values that will be concatenated with output table field headers. When choosing a Field Identifier value, please consider the following:

  • It should NOT start with underscore or a number.

param.name: emails
param.dialogReference: List of emails comma separated that will receive the output. When the process is finished, the result will be e-mailed to the recipients listed.
param.pythonReference: List of emails comma separated that will receive the output. When the process is finished, the result will be e-mailed to the recipients listed.

tool.summary: Calculates statistics on values of the land suitability raster within the zones of other dataset and reports the results in a number of tables.
tool.usage:
• A zone is defined as all areas in the input that have the same value. The areas do not have to be contiguous.

  • When the zone and value inputs are both rasters of the same resolution, they will be used directly.

    If the resolutions are different, an internal resampling is applied to make them match before the zonal operation is performed.

    Should there be any NoData cells in the inputs, the resampling may cause there to be larger areas of NoData in your output than you might have expected. To avoid this situation, either Resample the coarser input rasters to the resolution of the finer input raster.

  • Input raster zone data is not required to have an attribute table. The tool will generate it automatically.

  • If the reclassify option is NONE, no reclassification will be performed on the input raster zone data especially if it is made of integer values. Floating point and double precision input raster will be converted internally to a 32 bit signed integer for the purposes of generating an attribute table.

    If EQUAL INTERVAL option is used instead, the input raster zone data will be reclassified based on automatically generated class ranges. The number of classes is purely depended on the number of classes provided by the user. Using this option, by default, the input raster zone data will be classified into five classes.

    When using the RECLASSIFY BY TABLE option the following should be noted:

    • The input raster must have valid statistics. If the statistics do not exist, they can be created using the Calculate Statistics tool in the Data Management Tools toolbox.

    • The From value field, To value field, and New value field are the field names in the table that define the remapping. When defining values in the table, ensure field values are of the same numerical type. For instance on the ‘from field’ in the table, if your intention is to have float data types you could start with 0.0 or any other value provided that you explicitly include decimal point. Mixing value types (float types and integers) especially in applications such as MS Excel could lead to unexpected data types when used in an ArcGIS environment.

    • The values in the from and to fields can be of either float or integer numerical types. The assignment values in the new field must be integers.

    • To reclassify individual values, use a simple remap table of two items. The first item identifies the value to reclassify, and the other item identifies the value to assign to it. Set the 'to value field' the same as the 'from value field'. The value to assign to the output is 'new value field'.

    • To reclassify ranges of values, the remap table must have items defining the start and end of each range, along with the value to assign the range. The item defining the start of the range is the From value field, and the value defining the end of the range is the To value field. The value to assign to the output is Output value field.

    • The remap table can be an INFO table, a CSV, a .dbf file, an Access table, or a text file. .xls remap table fields will not be loaded.

    • Values in the from field for .dbf, INFO, and Geodatabase tables do not need to be sorted. For text-file based tables, they must be sorted in ascending order. The values should not overlap in either case.

  • If the Input value feature class is used, a vector-to-raster conversion will be internally applied to it. It is therefore imperative to ensure that feature dataset to be loaded is in the right coordinate system for the results of the conversion to align properly with the Input raster zone data.

  • The Input value feature class dataset is expected to have an attribute table with at least a single string field which will be loaded in the Feature field name. Any other data type is NOT allowed and will be filtered out if used.

  • To get a meaningful statistical output table, use polygon dataset instead of point in the Input value feature class field

  • The Input value raster table accepts a list of rasters that can either be of integer or floating point type.

  • For majority and minority calculations, when there is a tie, the output for the zone is based on the lowest of the tied values.

  • The Statistic Type field column in the Input value raster table, allows one of the following as a valid entry: ALL, MEAN, MAJORITY, MAX, MAXIMUM, MEDIAN, MINIMUM, MIN, MINORITY, RANGE, SUM, VARIETY, STD, SD, SN, SR, STDEV, STANDARD DEVIATION. A mixture of both lower case and upper case letters of the above types is allowed. The default value ALL.

  • Entries in the Output Table Name column should be string or alphanumeric values that meets all the requirements of a .dbf file name. Note that Output Table Name values should be unique.

  • Values in the Field Identifier column will be concatenated with fields in the individual statistics table outputs

  • All individual output statistics tables derived from each Input value raster, are to be joined to form a single table. For this to happen, each field header is expected to have a unique name by concatenating statistics type with values from the Field Identifier column. When choosing a Field Identifier value, please consider the following:

    • It should be unique.

    • It should NOT have more than two characters

    • Eliminate any character that is NOT alphanumeric or an underscore.

    • It should NOT start with underscore or a number.

  • The data type for each value in the output table is dependent on the zonal calculation being performed. See how Zonal Statistics works for the specific behavior of any statistic.

  • The number of rows in the output table is the number of zones.
